comment: Scandinavian defence - a solid, but inactive set up. In contrast, 13-year old Sasha Morozevich was fond of complicated play, sometimes even to the detriment of his position. But everything changes in our world - a couple of years later Morozevich himself started to play the Scandinavian for Black! For example, in CT-100 our editor Graham Brown mentioned the Gurevich - Morozevich game (London 1994).
reasoning: The comment does not directly explain the mistake made by the player. It discusses the player's style and a historical example of his game instead of analyzing the specific move in question.

comment: White has more space, and has a pawn d4 in the centre. But Black has developed his Bishop on f5 very successfully, and the pawns e6 and c6 create a "saw" for the d4 pawn. Of course White has a small advantage but it's very difficult to realise something real.
reasoning: The comment correctly highlights the mistake made by White due to overlooking Black's well-placed Bishop on f5 and the potential threat it poses to the pawn on d4.
